qas.question: What did the Origianl Spanish Students expect the African public not to know?

context: The mandolin's popularity in the United States was spurred by the success of a group of touring young European musicians known as the <a0_0><b5_0>Estudiantina Figaro<b5_0/><a0_0/>, or in the United States, simply the "Spanish Students." The group landed in the U.S. on <a1_0><b6_0>January 2, 1880<b6_0/><a1_0/> in New York City, and played in <a2_0><b7_0>Boston and New York<b7_0/><a2_0/> to wildly enthusiastic crowds. Ironically, this ensemble did not play mandolins but rather bandurrias, which are also small, double-strung instruments that resemble the mandolin. The success of the Figaro Spanish Students spawned other groups who imitated their musical style and costumes. An Italian musician, Carlo Curti, hastily started a musical ensemble after seeing the Figaro Spanish Students perform; his group of Italian born Americans called themselves the "<a3_0><b8_0>Original Spanish Students<b8_0/><a3_0/>," counting on the American public to not know <a4_0>the <b9_0>difference between the Spanish bandurrias and Italian mandolins<b9_0/><a4_0/>. The imitators' use of mandolins helped to generate enormous public interest in an instrument previously relatively unknown in the United States.
